The normal coloring matter of the red blood corpuscles of vertebrate animals. It is composed of hematin and globulin, and is also called haematoglobulin. In arterial blood, it is always combined with oxygen, and is then called oxyhemoglobin. It crystallizes under different forms from different animals, and when crystallized, is called haematocrystallin. See Blood crystal, under Blood.

The indirect division of cells in which, prior to division of the cell protoplasm, complicated changes take place in the nucleus, attended with movement of the nuclear fibrils; -- opposed to karyostenosis. Any young insect from the time that it hatches from the egg until it becomes a pupa, or chrysalis. During this time it usually molts several times, and may change its form or color each time. The larvae of many insects are much like the adults in form and habits, but have no trace of wings, the rudimentary wings appearing only in the pupa stage. In other groups of insects the larvae are totally unlike the parents in structure and habits, and are called caterpillars, grubs, maggots, etc.

the twenty-first letter of the English alphabet, is a cursive form of the letter V, with which it was formerly used interchangeably, both letters being then used both as vowels and consonants. U and V are now, however, differentiated, U being used only as a vowel or semivowel, and V only as a consonant. The true primary vowel sound of U, in Anglo-Saxon, was the sound which it still retains in most of the languages of Europe, that of long oo, as in tool, and short oo, as in wood, answering to the French ou in tour. Etymologically U is most closely related to o, y (vowel), w, and v; as in two, duet, dyad, twice; top, tuft; sop, sup; auspice, aviary. See V, also O and Y.

The act of carrying, or state of being carried.
A directed quantity, as a straight line, a force, or a velocity. Vectors are said to be equal when their directions are the same their magnitudes equal.  Cf. Scalar.
Growing, or having the power of growing, as plants; capable of vegetating.

The quality or state of being venal, or purchasable; mercenariness; prostitution of talents, offices, or services, for money or reward; as, the venality of a corrupt court; the venality of an official.
To infect with venom; to envenom; to poison.
A touchhole; a vent.
Verisimilitude.
Turned.
A change of form, direction, or the like; transformation; conversion; turning.
The reverse, or left-hand, page of a book or a folded sheet of paper; -- opposed to recto.
of Vertebra
A vesicatory.
To clothe with possession; as, to vest a person with an estate; also, to give a person an immediate fixed right of present or future enjoyment of; as, an estate is vested in possession.
of Vestryman
One who lets or drives a vettura.
To make angry or annoyed by little provocations; to irritate; to plague; to torment; to harass; to afflict; to trouble; to tease.
In a vexing manner; so as to vex, tease, or irritate.
The communion, or eucharist, when given to persons in danger of death.
A genus of motile bacteria characterized by short, slightly sinuous filaments and an undulatory motion; also, an individual of this genus.
Delegated office or power; vicarship; the office or oversight of a vicar.
Bitter; spiteful; malignant.
Subject to vicissitudes.
A woman's fur tippet.

To move staggeringly or unsteadily from one side to the other; to vacillate; to move the manner of a rotating disk when the axis of rotation is inclined to that of the disk; -- said of a turning or whirling body; as, a top wabbles; a buzz saw wabbles.
Woad.

A follower of Abdel Wahab (b. 1691; d. 1787), a reformer of Mohammedanism. His doctrines prevail particularly among the Bedouins, and the sect, though checked in its influence, extends to most parts of Arabia, and also into India.
of Waken
To move off; to depart.
A defense; a rampart; a means of protection; in the plural, fortifications, in general; works for defense.
of Wallaby
Any one of several species of kangaroos of the genus Macropus, especially M. robustus, sometimes called the great wallaroo.
The duty of keeping watch and ward (see the Note under Watch, n., 1) with a horn to be blown upon any occasion of surprise.
a. & n. from Warm, v.
See Warye.

The washing out or away of earth, etc., especially of a portion of the bed of a road or railroad by a fall of rain or a freshet; also, a place, especially in the bed of a road or railroad, where the earth has been washed away.
See Washboard, 3.
One who watches; one who sits up or continues; a diligent observer; specifically, one who attends upon the sick during the night.
Either of several tropical aquatic plants of the genus Eichhornia, related to the pickerel weed.
The level formed by the surface of still water.
See Water line, 2.
A variety of chicken pox, or varicella.
A liquid hydrocarbon of the terpene series extracted from the seeds of a Japanese prickly ash (Xanthoxylum pipertium) as an aromatic oil.
Of or pertaining to the xiphoid process; xiphoidian.
A genus of marine bivalves which bore holes in wood. They are allied to Pholas.
One of the forked holders for supporting the telescope of a leveling instrument, or the axis of a theodolite; a wye.
Same as Yacare.
A gate.  See 1st Gate.
To rise in blisters, breaking in white froth, as cane juice in the clarifiers in sugar works.
A sudden or quick thrust or motion; a jerk.
Alt. of Yester-evening
In addition; further; besides; over and above; still.
Alt. of Yodle
Fig.: That which connects or binds; a chain; a link; a bond connection.
To pour water on; to soak in, or mix with, water.
Being in the first part, pr period, of growth; as, a young plant; a young tree.
Wanting zeal.
A kind of cabinet wood having beautiful black, brown, and whitish stripes, the timber of a tropical American tree (Connarus Guianensis).
See Sequin.
A medicinal substance obtained in the East Indies, having a fragrant smell, and a warm, bitter, aromatic taste. It is used in medicine as a stimulant.
A nitrogenous substance of the nature of gluten, obtained from the seeds of Indian corn (Zea) as a soft, yellowish, amorphous substance.

The blind mole rat (Spalax typhlus), native of Eastern Europe and Asia. Its eyes and ears are rudimentary, and its fur is soft and brownish, more or less tinged with gray. It constructs extensive burrows.
Alt. of Zincing
A kind of monomania in which the patient believes himself transformed into one of the lower animals.
